Anyone get unreasonably annoyed at the mixing of Greek and Roman names? Mar is Roman, but Deimos and Phobos are Greek. Deimos should technically be Metus or Formido, and Phobos should be Timor, Timorus, or Pavor.

The lower pressure on mars will cause a huge problem with your body because the water under lower pressure boils at very low temperature not at 100 °C.

For instance, at the top of Mount Everest, water boils at 60 °C. But on Mars, where the atmosphere is much thinner than on Earth, it can boil at temperatures as low as 0 °C.

A renowned Turkish geology professor, Celal Şengör once made an experiment of that canyon in 3:24 , and is seriously claiming that it may be formed by collapsed icebergs and solid ice that had been heated by the magma. His theory was that there were huuuge water sources under that canyon, then the rising magma evaporated the solid ice, and the canyon just collapsed.


He even made an experiment on it, and aired it on television in Turkey, and was in touch with Nature magazine to have it tested as a serious hypothesis.

Two ways Venus would kill you (assuming that you are in a cloud city where the atmospheric pressure is pleasant):
- Asphyxiation
- Dissolving in the acid clouds
Solution? Air tank and acid-proof clothing.

Two ways Mars would kill you:
- Cancer from solar radiation
- Bones falling apart due to the low gravity of 0.4g
Solution? You'd need to terraform it somehow, add an atmosphere to absorb the radiation and somehow increase the surface gravity.

Venus = better option

How's this for conjecture:  The "internal dynamo," dissipated after the asteroid impact that created the northern planes.  So much energy could have been released from the interior of the planet that this perhaps shut of the magnetic field.  This could have happened a relatively short time ago and perhaps life even developed into more complex forms that single celled organisms.  There you have a basis for a manned mission:  Send some paleontologists to mars!

I love how Venus is basically Earth with too much greenhouse effect, and Mars is Earth with too little greenhouse effect. Both result in apocalyptic conditions.

I also find it interesting that the two planets nearest to us are polar opposites in terms of atmatmospheric disaster, suggesting distance from the sun directly impacts atmospheric density. This means that we call global warming/climate change may very well be a natural atmospheric phenomenon caused by celestial force rather than mankind's influence. Doesn't mean that we're ENTIRELY off the hook, though, as sending matter from Earth into space may have slightly disrupted the Earth's solar orbit by slightly reducing its total mass. If so, we may see the effect be reduced when we start returning matter from other planets to Earth, or when the variances stabilize.

My kids and I are doing Space Week this week and I found a great writing prompt/graphic organizer that asks the question, "If you were asked to join the first team of Mars explorers, would you go? Write a letter to NASA explaining your choice and give 3 reasons why or why not."

They are 7 and 10, both with special needs, and they have a general understanding of the solar system but we hadn't gone very far in depth on any of the specific planets. So we watched this video today (their first exposure to Crash Course) and while I know a fair bit of the vocabulary was beyond them, they loved the graphics and were able to repeat back to me a lot more than I expected them to retain. I showed them a few National Geographic videos about the Mars Rovers afterwards and they were both like, "Can we go back to the other guy?" 

So thanks, Phil and the team! The timing on this video was perfect and I can't wait to see the rest of the series.

I don't really understand this fascination with Mars, everyone wants to go there, as soon as possible. We have the Moon, right in our back yard so to speak, couldn't we test everything on the Moon first, then go to Mars? Hell, the Moon would be a great launch platform for a Mars mission: 6th the gravity of Earth, so the ship only needs 1/6th of the fuel required to defeat Earth's gravity.

This is how I see it. Lets go back to the Moon first. Start building a city there, infrastructure, mining and eventually a shipyard. All materials come from the Moon itself, and during the time that it takes to build all that, we can iron out all the details of how to live on Mars. You know, better toilets than the ISS has, cause they break all the godamn time. If I'm going to Mars, I need to know that at least my toilet won't act up on me, poop all over the cabin for 3 years (round trip) does not sound pleasant.

Once everything is in place, a ship can be built on the Moon, filled with fuel extracted (or manufactured) on the Moon and then eventually launched towards Mars.

If something goes wrong on the Moon, a nasty cold, apendix burst, pipe through your chest, alien attack, at least you can get back to Earth in a few days. If you're on Mars, well you are basically screwed, takes 1.5 years to get back. The Moon has its big brother Earth nearby, so you could watch same TV with only about 2 seconds delay, while sciencing away.

Sorry guys, but i don't understand why you are talking about the "Mystery of where the Mars water went". Earth (you know, this thing with significantly higher gravity than Mars, and with an electromagnetic shield, shielding most of it's atmosphere from solar winds) is loosing tons of water every day into space (and has been doing so since it's formation a few billion years ago) because radiation splits Water into H and OH radicals in the upper atmosphere and Earth's gravity is simply not strong enough to hold H back from escaping Earth's gravity field. So Earth's water reserves (assuming no new one would be created chemically) are continuously decreasing and have been doing so for the past 4.5 bn years.
Given, Mars is located further away from the Sun so its a little bit colder (but not that much on a nice mars day at noon) and this will reduce the velocity of the H created and therefore the average percentage of particles to have escape velocity, but it also has a significantly weaker gravity field requiring less escape velocity from H, and it is (nearly) totally unprotected from radiation. Also recall, that the mars atmosphere is pretty thin and therefore the vapor pressure of any existing water (be it fluid or solid) will be significantly higher than on earth. How do you think all the Iron on Mars got oxidized to Fe2O3 without molecular O2 in the mars atmorphere ? 
So where is the "mystery" that there is no water anymore ? Absence is exactly what anyone would expect and it should be pretty obvious, where it went.
I mean, if i fill a bathtub in the Sahara desert with water, it will also be no mystery to most people where the water has gone, if i look again 3 days later. (Hint: "Camels" is the wrong answer).

On a side note, I think its important to note that if we really (and I mean put a big effort, expended a ton a capital, and really went all out as a people) went after it we could be there in 5 yrs.  And I don't mean travel time.  I say this because interesting developments in surface space transport bringing the cost down.  Space X is a step in the right direction but Skylon (reaction engines ltd) is the Leap needed.  The other is the advancement of Ion drives and the like.  If we (the US) could get a nuclear reactor to power a spaceship.  That Ion drive system becomes something you see in Star Trek.  So to reiterate,  Skylon gets it up to space cheap, and a badass power source for your Ion drive gets you there fast.   We could have these things a lot sooner if people had the will.  We spent 2 Trillion on Iraq and Afghanistan, but we can't get One Dime to make a Starfleet..  Maybe it's better a space rock wipes us out.

Personally, I see the best plan for Mars to be a three steps. 

1. Humans underground in lava tubes
2. Para-terraforming (essentially large greenhouses on Mars, a bit like the Eden Project)
3. Full Terraforming (wildly unrealistic at the moment, but who knows in 500 years?)

It'd be helpful if there was some kind of economic incentive. Does anyone know about precious minerals on Mars? At the moment, I can't imagine anything being financially viable, but if we can get transport costs down there might one day be a some profit in it. Something like Hydrogen-3 on the Moon.

Not sure about the uncertainty of reason for Mars to not have an atmosphere and not have geological activity at the moment.
